{{refimprove|date=April 2010}} [[File:AN ALE-55 m02006120800272.jpg|thumb|AN/ALE-55 Fiber-Optic Towed Decoy]] The '''AN/ALE-55 Fiber-Optic Towed Decoy''', or '''ALE-55''', is an [[Radar jamming and deception|RF (Radio Frequency) countermeasure]] under development by [[BAE Systems]] [[BAE Systems Electronics, Intelligence & Support|Electronic Solutions]] for the [[F/A-18E/F Super Hornet]].
<!-- ==The System== -->
== Overview ==
The ALE-55 is an RF countermeasure designed to protect an aircraft from [[radar]] guided [[missile]]s. It consists of an aircraft-towed decoy and onboard electronics. It works together with the aircraft's [[electronic warfare]] system to provide radar jamming. In addition, it can also be used in a backup mode as a signal repeater, which allows it to lure incoming missiles away from their actual target.<ref name="BAE" /> It is currently in use with the F/A-18E/F Super hornet, but can be adapted to a wide variety of platforms with minimal modification.<ref name="DEAGEL">[http://www.deagel.com/Aircraft-Protection-Systems/ANALE-55_a001668002.aspx deagel.com ALE-55]</ref>
== Defensive Techniques ==
The ALE-55 provides three layers of defensive jamming against a radar-based threat: preventing radars from tracking, breaking radar locks, and acting as a target for incoming missiles.<ref name="BAE">[http://www.baesystems.com/ProductsServices/bae_prod_eis_fotd.html BAE Systems AN/ALE-55 Fiber-Optic Towed Decoy]</ref>
=== Suppression ===
The system detects a threat radar in its acquisition mode and tries to prevent it from locking by using jamming techniques. The onboard electronic warfare package analyzes the threat, while the towed decoy emits the jamming signals to confuse the tracking radar.
=== Deflection ===
In the case that a radar obtains a lock on the aircraft or decoy system, the electronics on board the aircraft analyze the emissions and then determine the optimum jamming technique to break the radar lock. The jamming is done by the decoy. The ALE-55 also possesses the useful ability to send out multiple jamming frequencies if more than one radar is locked on to the decoy or aircraft.
=== Seduction ===
When a missile launch is detected, indicated by the difference in radar signal and type, the ALE-55 runs a last resort attempt to protect the aircraft towing it. This last resort is becoming the target, rather than the aircraft, by trying to jam the missile or simulating the aircraft's radar signature.
== Components ==
The ALE-55 consists of two components. An onboard signal conditioning assembly and fiber optic towed decoys.<ref name="BAE" />
The onboard electric frequency converter analyzes radar signals detected by the plane's electronic warfare system and calculates an appropriate jamming and spoofing signal, which is then transmitted to the FOTD through a fiber optic cable.
The towed decoy has dual high power [[traveling-wave tube]]s (TWTs) to allow for enough power to protect large aircraft. It is launched with the Raytheon Integrated Multi-Platform Launch Controller (IMPLC), which it shares with the towed [[ALE-50]].<ref name="DID" /> An active braking system allows for fast deployment.
== Operators ==
;{{flagicon|AUS}} Australia *[[Royal Australian Air Force]]<ref name="DID">[http://www.defenseindustrydaily.com/ALE-55-Towed-Fighter-Decoys-for-US-Navy-Australia-05385/ ALE-55 Towed Fighter Decoys for US Navy, Australia]</ref>
;{{flagicon|USA}} United States *[[United States Navy]]
;{{flagicon|KSA}} Kingdom of Saudi Arabia *[[Royal Saudi Air Force]]
==See also== [[AN/ALE-50]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.baesystems.com/ProductsServices/bae_prod_eis_fotd.html www.baesystems.com]

{{EngvarB|date=October 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox engineer |name = Alice Perry |image = Alice Perry 1885-1969.jpg |image_size = 150 |caption = |nationality = Irish |birth_name = Alice Jacqueline Perry |birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1885|10|24}} |birth_place = Wellpark House, [[Galway]], Ireland |death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1969|04|21|1885|10|24}} |death_place = |education = [[Royal University of Ireland|Royal University of Ireland, Galway]] |spouse = John Shaw |parents = [[James Perry (engineer)|James Perry]] and Martha Perry |discipline = [[Civil engineering|Civil]] }}
'''Alice Jacqueline Perry''' (24 October 1885 – 21 April 1969) was a poet and the first woman in Ireland to graduate with a degree in engineering.<ref name="Engineers Ireland">{{cite web|last1=Engineers Ireland|title=Alice Perry (1885–1969)|url=http://www.realizedvision.com/ap.php|website=Engineers Ireland: Realised Vision|publisher=Engineers Ireland|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Born in [[Wellpark]], [[Galway]] in 1885, Alice was one of five daughters of James and Martha Perry (née Park).<ref name="Irish Architectural Archive">{{cite web|last1=Irish Architectural Archive|title=PERRY, ALICE JACQUELINE|url=http://www.dia.ie/architects/view/4332/PERRY-ALICEJACQUELINE|website=Dictionary of Irish Architects 1720–1940|publisher=Irish Architectural Archive|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref> Her father was the County Surveyor in Galway West and co-founded the Galway Electric Light Company.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Irish Architectural Archive|title=PERRY, JAMES|url=http://www.dia.ie/architects/view/4331/PERRY-JAMES|website=Dictionary of Irish Architects 1720–1940|publisher=Irish Architectural Archive|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref> Her uncle, [[John Perry (engineer)|John Perry]], was a Fellow of the [[Royal Society]] and invented the navigational gyroscope.<ref name="O'Connell" />
After graduating from the High School in Galway, she won a scholarship to study in [[Royal University of Ireland|Royal University, Galway]] in 1902. Having excelled in mathematics, she changed from studying for a degree in arts to an engineering degree. She graduated with first class honours in 1906.<ref name="Engineers Ireland" /><ref>{{cite web|last1=NUI Galway|title=Our history|url=http://www.nuigalway.ie/about-us/who-we-are/our-history.html|website=NUI Galway|publisher=NUI Galway|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref> The family appear to have been academically gifted. Her sisters Molly and Nettie also went on to third level education; a third sister Agnes earned BA (1903) and MA (1905) in mathematics from Queen's College Galway (later UCG then NUIG), taught there in 1903–1904, was a Royal University of Ireland examiner in mathematics in 1906, and later became assistant headmistress at a secondary school in London.<ref name="Galway Society">{{cite journal|last1=O'Sullivan|first1=M. D.|last2=O'Halloran|first2=Joe|title=The Centenary of Galway College|journal=Journal of the Galway Archaeological and Historical Society|year=1999|volume=51|pages=24–42}}</ref>
==Career== Following her graduation she was offered a senior postgraduate scholarship but owing to her father's death the following month, she did not take up this position.<ref name="Irish Architectural Archive" /> In December 1906 she succeeded her father temporarily as county surveyor for Galway County Council.<ref name="Irish Architectural Archive" /> She remained in this position for five<ref name="Irish Architectural Archive" /> or six<ref name="Engineers Ireland" /> months until a permanent appointment was made. She was an unsuccessful candidate for the permanent position and for a similar opportunity to be a surveyor in Galway East.<ref name="Irish Architectural Archive" /> She remains the only woman to have been a County Surveyor (County Engineer) in Ireland.<ref name="Engineers Ireland" />
In 1908 she moved to London with her sisters, where she worked as a Lady Factory Inspector for the [[Home Office]].<ref name="Engineers Ireland" /> From there she moved to [[Glasgow]], at which point she converted from [[Presbyterianism]] to [[Christian Science]] in 1915.<ref name="O'Connell">{{cite book|last1=O'Connell|first1=Claire|editor1-last=Mulvihill|editor1-first=Mary|title=Lab Coats and Lace|date=2009|publisher=WITS|location=Dublin|isbn=978-0-9531953-1-2|pages=43–45|ref=O'Connell|chapter=First in Their Field}}<!--|accessdate=8 February 2015--></ref> She met and married John (Bob) Shaw on 30 September 1916.<ref name="Irish Architectural Archive" /> Shaw was a soldier who died in 1917 on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]].<ref name="Engineers Ireland" /><ref name="Irish Architectural Archive" />
==Later life and death== Perry retired from her inspector's position in 1921<ref name="O'Connell" /> and became interested in poetry, first publishing in 1922.<ref name="Engineers Ireland" /> In 1923 she moved to [[Boston]], the headquarters of Christian Science.<ref name="O'Connell" /> Until her death in 1969, Perry worked within the Christian Science movement as a poetry editor and practitioner,<ref name="Irish Architectural Archive" /> publishing seven books of poetry.<ref name="Engineers Ireland" />
==Legacy== [[File:Alice Perry building NUI galway.jpg|thumb|Alice Perry building NUI galway]]
An All-Ireland medal has been named in her honour, The Alice Perry Medal, with the first prizes awarded in 2014.<ref name="NUI Galway">{{cite web|last1=NUI Galway|title=Winners announced for the First All-Ireland Apps Competition|url=http://www.nuigalway.ie/about-us/news-and-events/news-archive/2014/may2014/winners-announced-for-the-first-all-ireland-apps-competition-.html|website=NUI Galway|publisher=NUI Galway|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref>
On Monday 6 March 2017, [[NUI Galway]] held an official ceremony to mark the naming of the Alice Perry Engineering Building.<ref>{{cite web|title=Series of Events to celebrate Naming of Alice Perry Engineering Building at NUI Galway|url=https://www.nuigalway.ie/about-us/news-and-events/news-archive/2017/march2017/series-of-events-to-celebrate-naming-of-alice-perry-engineering-building-at-nui-galway.html|accessdate=8 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/engineers-ireland-laments-industry-s-stark-gender-imbalance-1.3000331|title=Engineers Ireland laments industry's 'stark' gender imbalance|date=6 March 2017|work=The Irish Times|access-date=13 March 2017|dead-url=}}</ref>
==Publications== * ''The children of Nazareth : and other poems'' (c1930) * ''The morning meal and other poems'' (1939) * ''Mary in the garden and other poems'' (1944) * ''One thing I know and other poems'' (c1953) * ''Women of Canaan and other poems'' (1961)
==See also== *[[Women in engineering]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
== Further reading ==
* Ó hÓgartaigh, Margaret (2002). '"Am I a Lady or an Engineer?" Early Irish Female Engineers', ''Irish Engineers' Journal'', December, pp. 48–49.
==External links== *[http://www.engineergirl.org/4356.aspx Great Women in Engineering History.] *[http://www.wes.org.uk/content/pioneering-women-engineers Pioneering Women Engineers.]

{{Infobox scientist | name = Alison L. Van Eenennaam | image = File:Alison_Van_Eenennaam.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = <!--{{birth date |YYYY|MM|DD}}--> | birth_place = [[Melbourne]], Australia | death_date = <!--{{death date and age |YYYY|MM|DD |YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date)--> | death_place = | other_names = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = | fields = {{hlist|Animal [[Genomics]]|[[Biotechnology]]}} | workplaces = [[University of California-Davis]] | patrons = | education = [[University of Melbourne]], [[Bachelor of Science]] [[Agricultural Science]], 1987; [[University of California, Davis]]; [[Master of Science]] [[Animal Science]], 1990; [[University of California, Davis]] [[Ph.D.]] [[Genetics]], 1997 | alma_mater = | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = research on animal cloning and genetic engineering of livestock and science communication | influenced = | awards = National Award for Excellence in Extension from the American Association of Public and Land-Grant Universities (2010) and [[Borlaug CAST Communication Award]] (2014) | spouse = Joel Van Eenennaam (1990–present) | partner = <!--(or | partners = )--> | children = 2 | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | website = {{URL|http://animalbiotech.ucdavis.edu/}} | footnotes = }} {{Primarysources|article|date=January 2018}} '''Alison L. Van Eenennaam''' is a Cooperative Extension Specialist in the Department of Animal Science at the [[University of California, Davis]] and runs the Animal [[Genomics]] and [[Biotechnology]] Laboratory.<ref>{{cite web|title=Animal Genomics and Biotechnology Laboratory|url=http://169.237.28.91/AnimalBiotech/My_Laboratory/index.htm|website=My Laboratory|accessdate=12 July 2017}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> She has served on national committees such as the [[USDA]] National Advisory Committee on Biotechnology in the 21st Century (AC21) and was awarded the 2014 [[Borlaug CAST Communication Award]]. Van Eenennaam writes the Biobeef Blog.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Van Eenennaam|first1=Alison|title=Biobeef Blog|url=http://biobeef.faculty.ucdavis.edu/|website=Biobeef Blog|accessdate=12 July 2017}}</ref>
== Education==
Van Eenennaam began her university career at the [[University of Melbourne]], [[Victoria, Australia]] in 1987, receiving a [[Bachelor of Science|BS]] (Honors) degree in [[Agricultural Science]]. She received a [[Master of Science]] degree in [[Animal Science]] in 1990, and a [[Ph.D]] in [[Genetics]] in 1997, both from [[University of California, Davis]].<ref name="HouseCV">{{cite web|last1=Van Eenennaam|first1=Alison|title=Bio|url=http://docs.house.gov/meetings/IF/IF14/20141210/102797/HHRG-113-IF14-Bio-VanEenennaamA-20141210.pdf|website=US House of Representatives Document Repository|publisher=US House of Representatives|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref>
==Career==
Van Eenennaam began her work in animal science as an intern at Genetic Resources Inc.'s Bovine Reproduction Facility in [[San Marcos, Texas]] in 1984. From 1991 to 1993 she worked as a livestock and dairy farm advisor for the [[Cooperative State Research, Education, and Extension Service|UC Cooperative Extension]] in the [[San Joaquin County, California|San Joaquin]] and [[Sacramento County, California|Sacramento]] Counties of [[California]]. From 1998 to 2002, following the completion of her [[Ph.D]] degree, Van Eenennaam worked for Calgene (purchased by [[Monsanto]] Corporation in 1997) in [[Davis, California]], first as a research scientist, and then as a project leader.<ref name="HouseCV"/> Since 2002, Van Eenennaam has been a Cooperative Extension Specialist in the field of Animal [[Genomics]] and [[Biotechnology]] in the Department of Animal Science at [[University of California, Davis]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Van Eenennaam|first1=Alison|title=About|url=http://biobeef.faculty.ucdavis.edu/about/|website=Biobeef Blog|accessdate=1 August 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170730065535/http://biobeef.faculty.ucdavis.edu/about/|archivedate=30 July 2017|df=}}</ref>
She has served on several national committees including the [[USDA]] National Advisory Committee on Biotechnology and 21st Century Agriculture, (2005–2009),<ref>{{cite web|title=Advisory Committee on Biotechnology & 21st Century Agriculture (AC21)|url=https://www.usda.gov/topics/biotechnology/advisory-committee-biotechnology-21st-century-agriculture-ac21|website=Biotechnology and 21st Century Agriculture|publisher=US Department of Agriculture|accessdate=9 August 2017}}</ref> and was a temporary voting member of the 2010 [[FDA]] Veterinary Medicine Advisory Committee meeting on the [[AquAdvantage salmon]], the first genetically engineered animal to be evaluated for entry into the food supply.<ref>{{cite web|title=2010 VMAC Meeting Materials|url=https://www.fda.gov/AdvisoryCommittees/CommitteesMeetingMaterials/VeterinaryMedicineAdvisoryCommittee/ucm201810.htm|website=Advisory Committees|publisher=US Food and Drug Administration|accessdate=9 August 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://wayback.archive-it.org/7993/20170404230911/https://www.fda.gov/AdvisoryCommittees/CommitteesMeetingMaterials/VeterinaryMedicineAdvisoryCommittee/ucm201810.htm|archivedate=4 April 2017|df=}}</ref>
==Research==
The mission of Van Eenennaam's animal biotechnology lab is to "provide research and education on the use of animal genomics and biotechnology in livestock production systems", with a focus on beef cattle production. <ref>{{cite web|title=Home|url=https://animalbiotech.ucdavis.edu/|website=Animal Biotechnology|publisher=UC Davis|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref> Van Eenennaam's biotechnology lab at UC Davis is working on a collaborative project focused on the production of hornless dairy cattle through [[Genome editing|gene editing]] on a USDA [[National Institute of Food and Agriculture]] grant.<ref>{{cite web|title=Improvement of Diary Animal Well-being by Genetic Dehorning|url=https://portal.nifa.usda.gov/web/crisprojectpages/1005738-improvement-of-diary-animal-well-being-by-genetic-dehorning.html|website=USDA Research, Education & Economics Information System|publisher=US Department of Agriculture|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref> This project involves using a gene sequence from [[Angus cattle]] in the genome of dairy cattle to prevent horns from growing. Van Eenennaam stated that the use of genetics rather than chemicals to solve problems can address some of the animal welfare concerns and environmental impacts of animal production.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Van Eenennaam|first1=Alison|title=002 Engineering Hornless Cows; Blueberry Origins|url=http://www.talkingbiotechpodcast.com/002-engineering-hornless-cows-blueberry-origins/|website=Talking Biotech Podcast|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref> In October, 2016, this project was featured on [[Science Friday]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Scientists Develop a Hornless Cow Through Gene Editing|url=https://www.sciencefriday.com/segments/scientists-develop-a-hornless-cow-through-gene-editing/|website=Science Friday|publisher=Science Friday Initiative|accessdate=21 September 2017}}</ref> Funding sources for this research and extension program are found on Van Eenennaam's public website.<ref>{{cite web|title=Research Projects|url=https://animalbiotech.ucdavis.edu/research-projects|website=Animal Biotechnology|publisher=UC Davis|accessdate=21 September 2017}}</ref>
Van Eenennaam was appointed to the [[Food and Drug Administration]] Veterinary Medicine Advisory Committee evaluating the [[AquAdvantage salmon]], a genetically engineered fish. A paper, authored in 2006 by Van Eenennaam with Paul Olin of University of California Cooperative Extension Sea Grant, discussed transgenic fish. The paper cites a number of benefits of genetically engineered fish, including a larger number of eggs laid per female, a low probability of carrying human pathogens, strong markets for [[aquaculture]], and increased [[Feed conversion ratio|feed-conversion efficiency]]. This paper also describes the risk factor that these fish could escape breeding locations and mix with wild fish populations.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Van Eenennaam|first1=Alison|last2=Olin|first2=Paul G.|title=Careful risk assessment needed to evaluate transgenic fish|journal=California Agriculture|date=2006|volume=60|issue=3|pages=126–131|url=http://escholarship.org/uc/item/9fx369v6}}</ref>
In 2014 Van Eenennaam co-authored a review article on the use of genetically modified feed for cattle.<ref name=pmid25184846>{{cite journal |doi=10.2527/jas.2014-8124 |pmid=25184846 |title=Erratum |journal=Journal of Animal Science |volume=92 |issue=11 |pages=4255-4278 |year=2014 |last1=Van Eenennaam |first1=A. L |last2=Young |first2=A. E }}</ref> The data represented more than 100 billion animals in 29 studies and found "GMO feed is safe and nutritionally equivalent to non-GMO feed".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jon|first1=Entine|title=The Debate About GMO Safety Is Over, Thanks To A New Trillion-Meal Study|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jonentine/2014/09/17/the-debate-about-gmo-safety-is-over-thanks-to-a-new-trillion-meal-study/#74dfdd958a63|website=Forbes.com|publisher=Formes|accessdate=6 September 2017}}</ref>
==Science outreach== Van Eenennaam won two awards from [[American Society of Animal Science]]. One was for the 2013 video ''Gene Shop'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Gene Shop|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lPQ8MPDFV64|website=YouTube|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=30 August 2017}}</ref> a five-minute parody of [[Macklemore]]’s “Thrift Shop” in which Dr. Van Eenennaam and UC Davis students engagingly emphasize the importance of funding for agricultural research. The second award was for the 2012 video ''Were Those the Days My friend?'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Were Those the Days My Friend|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6B-CH-NCdiY|website=YouTube|publisher=YouTube}}</ref> a take on a ballad from the 1960s that highlights the importance of genetic advances for improved production efficiency and food security. This competition was designed to further the "goal of sharing the importance of animal science with the public".<ref>{{cite web|title=Taking Stock|url=https://asas.org/taking-stock/taking-stock/2012/06/01/uc-davis-group-wins-asas-video-competition|website=American Association of Animal Science|publisher=AAAS|accessdate=30 August 2017}}</ref>
Additional YouTube videos on biotechnology topics are linked to the BioBeef Blog written by Van Eenennaam in order "to try to interject scientific nuance into these controversial and often politicized scientific topics".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Van Eenennaam|first1=Alison|title=Valentines Day 2016|url=http://biobeef.faculty.ucdavis.edu/2016/02/14/valentines-day-2016/|website=Biobeef Blog|accessdate=30 August 2017}}</ref> Van Eenennaam participated in the 2014 [[Intelligence Squared]] debate on the topic of genetically modify food.<ref>{{cite web|title=Genetically Modify Food|url=https://www.intelligencesquaredus.org/debates/genetically-modify-food|website=Intelligence Squared|publisher=Intelligence Squared US|accessdate=21 September 2017}}</ref>
In 2014, Van Eenennaam was awarded the [[Borlaug CAST Communication Award]] by the [[Council for Agricultural Science and Technology]] (CAST), named after agricultural biologist and 1970 [[Nobel Peace Prize]] winner [[Norman Borlaug]]. CAST indicated that Van Eenennaam is known for her communication skills and praised for her understanding of biotechnology, her enthusiasm for agricultural education, and her abilities to use novel ideas to get important messages to policymakers and the public alike.<ref name="CAST">{{cite web|title=Alison Van Eenennaam|url=https://www.cast-science.org/borlaug_cast_communication_award/laureates/bcca_laureates/alison-van-eenennaam/|website=Borlaug CAST Communication Award|publisher=Council for Agricultural Science and Technology|accessdate=2 August 2017}}</ref>
Van Eenennaam appeared in the 2016 documentary production, ''Food Evolution'', written and produced by Trace Sheehan and [[Scott Hamilton Kennedy]]. The film, narrated by [[Neil deGrasse Tyson]], features scientific experts in the areas of genetics, biology, biotechnology, and nutrition, as well as farmers and activists discussing the problems of feeding a growing global population.<ref>{{cite web|title=Press Kit|url=https://www.foodevolutionmovie.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/FoodEvolutionPressKit.pdf|website=Food Evolution|accessdate=12 September 2017}}</ref>
==Awards== * 2005 The Communicator “Award of Distinction” for “Genetic Engineering in California Agriculture” video.<ref name="DeptBio">{{cite web|title=UC Davis Department of Animal Science|url=http://animalscience.ucdavis.edu/faculty/vaneenennaam/|website=Van Eenennaam|publisher=The Regents of the University of California, Davis campus|accessdate=2 August 2017}}</ref> * 2009 The Communicator “Award of Distinction” for “Animal Biotechnology” video production <ref name="DeptBio"/> * 2010 American Association of Public and Land-Grant Universities (APLU), 2010 National Award for Excellence in Extension <ref>{{cite web|title=Excellence in Extension Awards|url=http://www.aplu.org/members/commissions/food-environment-and-renewable-resources/board-on-agriculture-assembly/cooperative-extension-section/extension-directors-and-administrators/awards/awards.pdf|website=Association of Public and Land Grant Universities|publisher=APLU|accessdate=2 August 2017}}</ref> * 2014 American Society of Animal Science Extension Award <ref>{{cite web|title=Dr. Alison L. Van Eenennaam|url=https://www.asas.org/about/national-awards/past-awardees/award-winner-detail/dr.-alison-l.-van-eenennaam|website=American Society of Animal Science|publisher=ASAS|accessdate=2 August 2017}}</ref> * 2014 Council for Agricultural Science and Technology (CAST) Borlaug Communication Award<ref name="CAST"/> * 2016 Beef Improvement Federation (BIF) Continuing Service Award <ref>{{cite web|title=2016 Awards|url=http://www.bifconference.com/bif2016/awards/2016ContinuingServiceVanEenennaam.htm|website=2016 Beef Improvement Federation Research Symposium and Convention|publisher=Beef Improvement Federation|accessdate=8 August 2017}}</ref> * 2016 BIO 2016 Future Maker Award<ref>{{cite web|title=Meet the BIO Future Makers|url=http://convention.bio.org/futuremakers/|website=BIO International Convention|publisher=Biotechnology Innovation Organization|accessdate=8 August 2017}}</ref> * 2017 [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] Fellow - Section on Agriculture, Food, and Renewable Resources <ref>{{cite web|last1=Van Eenennaam|first1=Alison|title=2017 AAAS Fellows Recognized for Advancing Science|url=https://www.aaas.org/news/2017-aaas-fellows-recognized-advancing-science|website=American Association for the Advancement of Science|publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science|accessdate=21 November 2017}}</ref>
==Articles== Van Eenennaam has authored or co-authored more than 80 academic articles. The following are selected articles in which Van Eenennaam is listed as the lead author.<ref>{{PubMedAuthorSearch|Van Eenennaam|AL}}</ref> *{{cite journal |doi=10.2527/jas.2010-3223 |pmid=21262975 |title=The value of using DNA markers for beef bull selection in the seedstock sector |journal=Journal of Animal Science |volume=89 |issue=2 |pages=307–20 |year=2011 |last1=Van Eenennaam |first1=A. L |last2=Van Der Werf |first2=J. H. J |last3=Goddard |first3=M. E }} *Van Eenennaam, A. L. E. M. Hallerman, and W.M. Muir. 2011. The Science and Regulation of Food from Genetically Engineered Animals. Council for Agricultural Science and Technology (CAST) Commentary QTA2011-2. CAST, Ames, Iowa.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Van Eenennaam|first1=Alison|title=The Science and Regulation of Food from Genetically Engineered Animals|url=https://www.cast-science.org/publications/index.cfm/the_science_and_regulation_of_food_from_genetically_engineered_animals?show=product&productID=21628|publisher=Council for Agricultural Science and Technology|accessdate=25 August 2017}}</ref> *{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/nbt.1938 |pmid=21822244 |title=Transgenic salmon: A final leap to the grocery shelf? |journal=Nature Biotechnology |volume=29 |issue=8 |pages=706–10 |year=2011 |last1=Van Eenennaam |first1=Alison L |last2=Muir |first2=William M }} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1071/AN11060 |title=Where in the beef-cattle supply chain might DNA tests generate value? |journal=Animal Production Science |volume=52 |issue=3 |pages=185–96 |year=2012 |last1=Van Eenennaam |first1=Alison L |last2=Drake |first2=Daniel J }} *{{cite journal |last1=Van Eenennaam |first1=A.L. |first2=W. M. |last2=Muir |first3=E. A. |last3=Hallerman |year=2013 |title=Is Unaccountable Regulatory Delay and Political Interference Undermining the FDA and Hurting American Competitiveness? The '''aviation transponder interrogation modes''' are the standard formats of pulsed sequences from an interrogating [[Secondary Surveillance Radar]] (SSR) or similar [[Automatic Dependent Surveillance-Broadcast]] (ADS-B) system. The reply format is usually referred to as a "code" from a [[Transponder (aviation)|transponder]], which is used to determine detailed information from a suitably equipped aircraft. In its simplest form, a "Mode" or interrogation type, is generally determined by pulse spacing between two or more interrogation pulses. Various modes exist from Mode 1 to 5 for military use, to Mode A, B, C and D and Mode S for civilian use. ==Interrogation modes== Several different RF [[communication protocol]]s have been standardized for aviation transponders: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Military
mode !! Civilian
mode !! Description |- |style="text-align:center"| 1 || || Provides 2-digit 5-bit mission code (cockpit selectable)[[NATO]] [[STANAG]] 4193 |- |style="text-align:center"| 2 || || Provides 4-digit octal unit code (set on ground for fighters, can be changed in flight by transport aircraft) |- |rowspan="2" style="text-align:center" | 3 ||style="text-align:center"| A || Provides a 4-digit octal identification code for the aircraft, set in the cockpit but assigned by the air traffic controller. Mode 3/A is often combined with Mode C to provide altitude information as well. |- |style="text-align:center"| C || Provides the aircraft's [[pressure altitude]] and is usually combined with Mode 3/A to provide a combination of a 4-digit octal code and altitude as Mode 3 A/C, often referred to as Mode A and C |- |style="text-align:center"| 4 || || Provides a 3-pulse reply, delay is based on the encrypted challenge |- |style="text-align:center"| 5 || || Provides a [[Cryptography|cryptographically]] secured version of Mode S and [[Automatic Dependent Surveillance-Broadcast|ADS-B]] GPS position |- |colspan="2" style="text-align:center"| S || Provides multiple information formats to a selective interrogation. Each aircraft is assigned a fixed 24-bit address.Peppler, I.L.: ''From The Ground Up'', pages 238–239. Aviation Publishers Co. Limited, Ottawa Ontario, Twenty Seventh Revised Edition, 1996. {{ISBN|0-9690054-9-0}} |} ===Mode A=== When the transponder receives an interrogation request, it broadcasts the configured transponder code (or "[[Transponder code|squawk code]]"). This is referred to as "Mode 3A" or more commonly, Mode A. A separate type of response called "Ident" can be initiated from the airplane by pressing a button on the transponder control panel. ===Mode A with Mode C=== A Mode A transponder code response can be augmented by a [[pressure altitude]] response, which is then referred to as Mode C operation. Pressure altitude is obtained from an altitude encoder, either a separate self-contained unit mounted in the aircraft or an integral part of the transponder. The altitude information is passed to the transponder using a modified form of the modified [[Gray code]] called a [[Gillham code]]. Mode A and C responses are used to help air traffic controllers identify a particular aircraft's position and altitude on a radar screen, in order to maintain separation. ===Mode S=== {{see also|Air traffic control radar beacon system#Mode S}} {{see also|Secondary surveillance radar#Mode S}} Another mode called Mode S (Select) is designed to help avoiding overinterrogation of the transponder (having many radars in busy areas) and to allow automatic collision avoidance. Mode S transponders are compatible with Mode A and Mode C [[Secondary Surveillance Radar]] (SSR) systems. This is the type of transponder that is used for TCAS or ACAS II ([[Airborne Collision Avoidance System]]) functions, and is required to implement the extended squitter broadcast, one means of participating in [[Automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast|ADS-B]] systems. A TCAS-equipped aircraft must have a Mode S transponder, but not all Mode S transponders include TCAS. Likewise, a Mode S transponder is required to implement 1090ES extended squitter ADS-B Out, but there are other ways to implement ADS-B Out (in the U.S. and China.) The format of Mode S messages is documented in ICAO Doc 9688, ''Manual on Mode S Specific Services''.{{Cite book | title = Manual on Mode S Specific Services | year = 2004 | edition = 2nd | isbn = 92-9194-407-6 | publisher = International Civil Aviation Organization | url = http://www.icao.int/isbn/Lists/Publications/DispForm.aspx?ID=420 }} ====Mode S features==== Upon interrogation, Mode S transponders transmit information about the aircraft to the [[Secondary Surveillance Radar|SSR]] system, to [[TCAS]] receivers on board aircraft and to the [[ADS-B]] SSR system. This information includes the [[List of airline call signs|call sign]] of the aircraft and/or the aircraft's permanent ICAO 24-bit address (which is represented for human interface purposes as six hexadecimal characters. One of the hidden features of Mode S transponders is that they are backwards compatible; an aircraft equipped with a Mode S transponder can still be used to send replies to Mode A or C interrogations. This feature can be activated by a specific type of interrogation sequence called inter-mode.{{Citation needed|date=August 2016}} =====ICAO 24-bit address===== Mode S equipped aircraft are assigned a unique ICAO 24-bit address or (informally) Mode-S "hex code" upon national registration and this address becomes a part of the aircraft's [[Aircraft registration|Certificate of Registration]]. Normally, the address is never changed, however, the transponders are reprogrammable and, occasionally, are moved from one aircraft to another (presumably for operational or cost purposes), either by maintenance or by changing the appropriate entry in the aircraft's [[Flight management system]]. There are 16,777,214 (224-2) unique ICAO 24-bit addresses (hex codes) available.{{cite web|url=http://www.caa.co.uk/default.aspx?catid=810&pagetype=90&pageid=6907 |title=UK Civil Aviation Authority – "ICAO 24 bit Aircraft Addresses" |publisher=Caa.co.uk |date=2007-10-02 |accessdate=2013-02-07}}{{cite web|url=http://www.eurocontrol.int/msa/public/standard_page/modes_tech_overview.html |title=Eurocontrol – "Mode S Technical Overview" |publisher=Eurocontrol.int |date= |accessdate=2013-02-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130331041052/http://www.eurocontrol.int/msa/public/standard_page/modes_tech_overview.html |archivedate=2013-03-31 |df= }} The ICAO 24-bit address can be represented in three digital formats: [[hexadecimal]], [[octal]], and [[Binary numeral system|binary]]. These addresses are used to provide a unique identity normally allocated to an individual aircraft or registration. As an example, following is the ICAO 24-bit address assigned to the [[Shuttle Carrier Aircraft]] with the [[aircraft registration|registration]] N905NA:{{cite web|author=Ralf D. Kloth, DL4TA, Ludwigsburg, DE |url=http://www.kloth.net/radio/icao24lookup.php |title=Aircraft on HFDL - ICAO 24 bit ID |publisher=Kloth.Net |date= |accessdate=2013-02-07}}{{cite web |url=http://www.airframes.org/ |title=Aircraft Database |website=Airframes.org |date=2005-08-11 |accessdate=2013-02-07}} * Hexadecimal: AC82EC * Octal: 53101354 * Binary: 101011001000001011101100 ''(Note: occasionally, spaces are added for visual clarity, thus 1010 1100 1000 0010 1110 1100 {[[Hexadecimal|Hex]] [[little endian]]} and 001 101 110 100 000 100 110 101 {[[Octal]] [[big endian]]})'' * Decimal: 11305708 These are all the same 24-bit address of the Shuttle Carrier Aircraft, represented in [[Radix|different numeral systems]] (see above). ====Issues with Mode S transponders==== An issue with Mode S transponders arises, when pilots enter the wrong [[call sign|flight identity]] code into the Mode S transponder. {{cite web|url = http://www.icao.int/icao/en/ro/apac/2005/ADSB_ADSB_TF3/ip13.pdf|format=PDF|title = The Third Meeting of Automatic Dependent Surveillance – Broadcast (ADS-B) Study and Implementation Task Force (ADS-B TF/3) |accessdate = 2008-03-28|author = International Civil Aviation Organization|date=March 2005}} In this case, the capabilities of [[ACAS II]] and Mode S [[Secondary surveillance radar|SSR]] can be degraded.[http://www.icao.int/icao/en/ro/apac/2005/ADSB_ADSB_TF3/ip13.pdf Eurocontrol – Aeronautical Information Circular (AIC) – ICAO 24-Bit Aircraft Addresses and Aircraft Identification Reporting] (in Minutes from The Third Meeting of the Automatic Dependent Surveillance – Broadcast (ADS-B) Study and Implementation Task Force (ADS-B TF/3)) ====Extended squitter==== {{see also|Secondary surveillance radar#Extended squitter}} In 2009 the ICAO published an "extended" form of Mode S with more message formats to use with [[ADS-B]];{{Cite book | title = ICAO Doc 9871, Technical Provisions for Mode S and Extended Squitter | isbn = 978-92-9231-117-9 | year = 2008 | author = ICAO | publisher = International Civil Aviation Organization | edition = 1st | url = http://www.icao.int/isbn/Lists/Publications/DispForm.aspx?ID=1129}} it was further refined in 2012.{{Cite book | title = ICAO Doc 9871, Technical Provisions for Mode S and Extended Squitter | isbn = 978-92-9249-042-3 | year = 2012 | author = ICAO | publisher = International Civil Aviation Organization | edition = 2nd | url = http://www.icao.int/isbn/Lists/Publications/DispForm.aspx?ID=2052 }} Countries implementing ADS-B can require the use of either the extended squitter mode of a suitably-equipped Mode S transponder, or the [[Automatic_dependent_surveillance_–_broadcast#Universal_access_transceiver|UAT]] transponder on 978 MHz. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} [[Category:Radar]] [[Category:Microwave technology]] [[Category:Measuring instruments]] [[Category:Navigational equipment]] [[Category:Air traffic control]]

[[File:Batoning.jpg|thumb|Batoning a piece of wood]] '''Batoning''' is the technique of cutting or splitting wood by using a [[club (weapon)|baton]]-sized stick or [[mallet]] to repeatedly strike the spine of a sturdy [[knife]], [[chisel]] or [[blade]] in order to drive it through wood, similar to how a [[froe]] is used.<ref>''[https://books.google.com/books?id=tjs85I4_TWwC Field & Stream]'' Mar 2006, p.45</ref><ref>''[https://books.google.com/books?id=4WiaMCK0kJcC&pg=PA110 Field & Stream]'' Dec 2008 - Jan 200, p.113</ref><ref>''[https://books.google.com/books?id=mfc_M6bXNv8C&pg=PA175 98.6 Degrees: The Art of Keeping Your Ass Alive!]'', Cody Lundin, Russ Miller, p.175</ref><ref>''[https://books.google.com/books?id=mPfo9ect6fsC Fundamentals of search and rescue]'', Donald C. Cooper, p.72</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leevalley.com/en/wood/page.aspx?p=67735&cat=51&ap=2 |title=Batoning Chisel - Lee Valley Tools |publisher=Leevalley.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-02}}</ref> The batoning method can be used to make kindling or desired forms such as boards, slats or notches. The practice is most useful for obtaining dry wood from the inside of logs for the purpose of [[fire making]].
==Tools== Tools used in batoning are: a strong, fixed-blade, preferably full tang knife or [[machete]] with a thick spine, and a club-sized length of dense or [[green wood]] for striking the knife's spine and tip.
==Technique== The basic method involves repeatedly striking the spine of the knife to force the middle of the blade into the wood. The tip is then struck, to continue forcing the blade deeper, until a split is achieved.<ref>McCann, John D.. Stay Alive: Survival Skills You Need. Krause Publications (24 Oct 2011).</ref>
==Uses and advantages== This technique is useful for the simple splitting of wood for kindling, to access dry wood within a wet log, and for the production of shingles, slats, or boards. It is also useful for cutting notches, or making clean crosscuts against the grain of the wood.{{Citation needed|date=April 2014}} The technique is also especially useful when a chopping tool is not available.
==Hazards== Care must be taken to avoid damage to the knife. Breakage of the blade is a common result of striking the spine of the knife at an angle. If this happens the broken blade can become irretrievably embedded within the split. In a survival situation, this can be catastrophic.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://shilohtv.com/?p=6494 |title=Batoning: How to Safely Baton With Your Knife (With Video) |publisher=ShilohTV |date=2010-05-15 |accessdate=2011-12-02}}</ref>

{{Infobox laboratory | name = Clinatec | native_name = | image = | caption = | latin_name = | motto = | established = {{start date|2011|}} | type = | budget = | debt = | research_field = Biomedical | president = [[Alim Louis Benabid]] | vice-president = | dean = | director = Stéphan Charbades (medical director) | head_label = | head = | faculty = | staff = 100 | students = | alumni = | address = | city = [[Grenoble]] | state = | province = | country = [[France]] | coor = {{Coord|45|11|33|N|5|42|29|E|}} | zipcode = | campus = | free_label = | free = | affiliations = [[French Alternative Energies and Atomic Energy Commission|CEA]], [[Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Grenoble|CHU Grenoble Alpes]] | operating_agency = | nobel_laureates = | website = http://www.clinatec.fr/en/ | logo = | footnotes = }} {{Location map | France | relief = yes | caption = [[Grenoble]] | alt = Clinatec is located in Grenoble | label = | mark = Red_pog.svg | marksize = 10 | lat_deg = 45 | lat_min = 11 | lat_sec = 33 | lat_dir = N | lon_deg = 5 | lon_min = 42 | lon_sec = 29 | lon_dir = E }} '''Clinatec''' is a [[biomedical]] research center based at the [[Polygone Scientifique]] in [[Grenoble]]. Doctors, biologists and [[Portal:Nanotechnology|micro- and nanotechnology]] experts work side-by-side at the 6,000 m² facility. Around a hundred researchers and employees work at the center. When it opened at the end of 2011, it was hailed as the first center of its kind in the world.<ref>[http://www-leti.cea.fr/fr/Decouvrez-le-Leti/Les-plateformes-d-innovation/Plateforme-Clinatec Website of Leti] ([[CEA-Leti: Laboratoire d'électronique des technologies de l'information|CEA-Leti]])</ref><ref>[http://www.isere-magazine.fr/sante/Pages/2012/Clinatec.aspx Isère magazine décembre 2012]</ref> With six hospital rooms, cutting-edge medical imaging equipment and an operating suite, Clinatec was developed by the Research Division of the [[French Alternative Energies and Atomic Energy Commission|CEA (French Alternative Energies and Atomic Energy Commission)]], [[Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Grenoble|Grenoble-Alpes University Hospital (CHU)]], [[Inserm]] and the [[Université Grenoble Alpes]]. The primary focus is on [[cancer]],<ref>[http://www.clinatec.fr/en/challenges_/fight-cancer/ Fight cancer]</ref> [[neurodegenerative diseases]]<ref>[http://www.clinatec.fr/en/challenges_/a-cure-for-parkinson/ A cure for Parkinson's disease]</ref> and [[disability]].<ref>[http://www.clinatec.fr/en/challenges_/get-quadraplegics-walking/ Get quadraplegics walking]</ref>
== Background == Professor [[Alim Louis Benabid]] and Jean Therme first met back in 2006.
Alim Louis Benabid is a neurosurgeon. Together with Professor Pierre Pollak, he developed a new treatment for [[Parkinson's disease]], [[deep brain stimulation]]. His work received recognition in 2014 with the [[Lasker Award]]<ref>[http://www.laskerfoundation.org/awards/show/deep-brain-stimulation-for-parkinsons-disease/ Lasker Award]</ref> and in 2016 with the [[European Inventor Award]].<ref>[http://www.epo.org/news-issues/press/releases/archive/2016/20160609d.html European Inventor Award 2016]</ref>
Jean Therme is Director of Technological Research at CEA Grenoble.<ref>[http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/connaissance/membres%20consscientif/Therme%20Jean.pdf Jean Therme]</ref> He has worked tirelessly to make Grenoble a key center of expertise in electronics and [[Portal:Nanotechnology|micro- and nanotechnology]], and to encourage close collaboration between the worlds of research and industry.<ref>[http://www.lesechos.fr/11/06/2013/LesEchos/21454-051-ECH_faire-marcher-un-paralyse---le-defi-du-cea.htm The challenge taken up by the French CEA: get quadriplegics walking]</ref>
Both men were convinced that millions of lives could be transformed by merging medical research and technology R&D. They agreed that the way to achieve this would be to bring together doctors, researchers, biologists, engineers, robotics engineers, mathematicians and knowledge engineers to work at a single site.
In 2010–11, the 6,000 m² building was built and equipped.<ref>[http://www.giant-grenoble.org/en/biotechnology-for-healthcare-platforms/ Biotechnology for Healthcare Platforms]</ref>
In 2013, the first patient was admitted to the center,<ref>[http://www.lopinion.fr/10-juin-2014/a-clinatec-technomedecine-a-l-assaut-d-alzheimer-13174 First patient]</ref> in relation to the "Protool" clinical trial coordinated by Professor Berger. For the first time, it was possible to use non-invasive procedures to explore regions of the brain that had hitherto been inaccessible. The exciting prospects opened up by this technology, the result of the coupling of technology developed at [[CEA-Leti: Laboratoire d'électronique des technologies de l'information|CEA-Leti]] with the clinical approach taken by researchers at [[Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Grenoble|Grenoble-Alpes University Hospital (CHU)]], [[Inserm]] and the [[Université Grenoble Alpes]], led to setting up the MedPrint start-up, which won an I-lab award in 2015.<ref>[http://www.clinatec.fr/une-stratup-de-clinatec-remporte-le-grand-prix-lab I-Lab Reward]</ref>
In 2014, Clinatec launched a campaign to raise 30 million euros in order to develop a number of projects,<ref>[http://acteursdeleconomie.latribune.fr/strategie/marketing-communication/2016-06-03/clinatec-30-millions-d-euros-pour-un-centre-de-recherche-du-futur.html Clinatec 30 million euros for a research center of futur]</ref><ref>[http://www.lepoint.fr/editos-du-point/anne-jeanblanc/clinatec-les-malades-n-ont-pas-le-temps-d-etre-patients-07-03-2016-2023476_57.php Patients can't afford to be patient]</ref> including: *the Brain Computer Interface (BCI) project<ref>[http://www.clinatec.fr/recherche/nos-projets/le-projet-bci/ BCI Project]</ref> aiming to prove that a quadriplegic patient can drive neuroprosthetic effectors with multiple degrees of freedom, such as an exoskeleton, based on decoding cortical signals (ElectroCorticoGrams) measured by a Wimagine implant, and can do this through training to make the most of their cerebral plasticity, *and the Near InfraRed (NIR) project<ref>[http://www.clinatec.fr/recherche/nos-projets/le-projet-nir/ NIR Project]</ref> aiming to demonstrate that near-infrared light can have neuro-protective effects in treating Parkinson's disease.
== Founding Members == [[File:Clinatec.JPG|Clinatec|thumb|200px]]
Clinatec is the outcome of a solid partnership between the [[French Alternative Energies and Atomic Energy Commission|CEA (French Alternative Energies and Atomic Energy Commission)]], [[Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Grenoble|Grenoble-Alpes University Hospital (CHU)]], [[Inserm]] and the [[Université Grenoble Alpes]].
== The clinatec endowment fund == The Clinatec [[endowment fund]] was set up in 2014. A sponsorship campaign has been launched, aiming to raise 30 million euros by 2018.<ref>[http://acteursdeleconomie.latribune.fr/strategie/marketing-communication/2016-06-03/clinatec-30-millions-d-euros-pour-un-centre-de-recherche-du-futur.html Clinatec 30 million euros for a research center of futur]</ref><ref>[http://www.lepoint.fr/editos-du-point/anne-jeanblanc/clinatec-les-malades-n-ont-pas-le-temps-d-etre-patients-07-03-2016-2023476_57.php Patients can't afford to be patient]</ref>
== Awards ==
=== Lasker Award === Professor [[Alim Louis Benabid]], Clinatec's founder and Chairman of the Board, member of the [[French Academy of Sciences]], is one of the joint winners of the prestigious [[Lasker Award|Albert-Lasker Award]]<ref>[http://www.laskerfoundation.org/awards/show/deep-brain-stimulation-for-parkinsons-disease/ Lasker Award 2014]</ref> for clinical research awarded by the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation in New York.<ref>[http://www.laskerfoundation.org/ Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation]</ref><ref>[[Lasker Award]] has gained a reputation for identifying future winners of the Nobel Prize. Eighty-six Lasker laureates have received the Nobel Prize, including 32 in the last two decades</ref> Professors Alim-Louis Benabid and Mahlon R. Delong of Emory University received awards for their contributions to the development of [[deep brain stimulation]]. The technique consists in stimulating the subthalamic nucleus to inhibit tremors and restore motor function in patients suffering from Parkinson's disease and from complications caused by [[L-DOPA|Levodopa]], a drug widely used in treating the disease.
=== Breakthrough Prize in Life Sciences === Set up in 2013 by [[Mark Zuckerberg]] and Priscilla Chan of [[Facebook]], [[Sergey Brin]], founder of [[Google]], and [[Yuri Milner]] and [[Anne Wojcicki]], the founders of [[23andMe]], the [[Breakthrough Prize in Life Sciences]] is awarded to researchers whose work extends human life expectancy.<ref>https://breakthroughprize.org/Laureates/2/P1/Y2015 Breakthrough Prize 2015</ref> Professor [[Alim Louis Benabid]] was awarded the prize in 2015 for the development of [[deep brain stimulation]], a technique which has revolutionized the treatment of [[Parkinson’s disease]].
=== European Inventor Award 2016 === On June 9, 2016, Professor [[Alim Louis Benabid]] received the [[European Inventor Award]] 2016<ref>[http://www.epo.org/news-issues/press/releases/archive/2016/20160609d.html European Inventor Award 2016]</ref> for his work on [[deep brain stimulation]]. The technique, now used all over the world, has radically transformed the lives of more than 150,000 people suffering from Parkinson's disease, and significantly improved their quality of life.
== Media interest == In July 2012, Philippe Pozzo di Borgo, rendered quadriplegic following an accident and the man whose story was the inspiration for the French film [[The Intouchables|Intouchables]], visited Clinatec with a group of local journalists. He expressed his confidence in and admiration for this research program in a report aired on regional news channel, [[France 3 Alpes]]<ref>[http://france3-regions.francetvinfo.fr/alpes/info/le-heros-d-intouchables-a-clinatec-74779742.html Hero's Intouchables visiting Clinatec]</ref>
== See also == *[[Brain–computer interface|Brain computer interface]] *[[Minatec]]

{{short description|One of the world's earliest sewage systems}} [[File:Map of downtown Rome during the Roman Empire large-annotated.jpg|thumb|300px|Map of central Rome during the time of the Roman Empire, showing Cloaca Maxima in red]]
The '''Cloaca Maxima'''{{refn|group=n|Less often, '''Maxima Cloaca'''.}} ({{lang-it|Cloaca Massima}}, lit. ''Greatest Sewer'', i.e. ''Main'') has constituted one of the world's earliest [[sewage system]]s. Constructed in [[Ancient Rome]] in order to drain local marshes and remove the waste of one of the world's most populous [[city|cities]], it carried effluent to the River [[Tiber]], which ran beside the city.<ref>Aldrete, Gregory S. (2004). ''Daily life in the Roman city: Rome, Pompeii and Ostia''. Greenwood Publishing Group. {{ISBN|978-0-313-33174-9}}, pp.34-35.</ref>
==Construction== According to tradition, it may have been initially constructed around 600 BC under the orders of the [[monarch|king]] of Rome, [[Tarquinius Priscus]].<ref name="iath.virginia.edu">[http://www.iath.virginia.edu/rome/Journal4Hopkins.pdf Waters of Rome Journal - 4 - Hopkins.indd<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The Cloaca Maxima originally was built by the [[Etruscan civilization|Etruscan]]s as an open-air canal. Over time, the Romans covered over the canal and expanded it into a sewer system for the city.<ref>Hopkins, John N. N. "The Cloaca Maxima and the Monumental Manipulation of water in Archaic Rome". Institute of the Advanced Technology in the Humanities. Web. 4/8/12</ref>
This public work was largely achieved through the use of Etruscan engineers and large amounts of semi-forced labour from the poorer classes of Roman citizens. Underground work is said to have been carried out on the sewer by [[Tarquinius Superbus]], Rome's seventh and last king.<ref>[[Livy]], ''[[Ab urbe condita (book)|Ab urbe condita]]'', 1.56</ref>
Although [[Livy]] describes it as being tunnelled out beneath Rome, he was writing centuries after the event. From other writings and from the path that it takes, it seems more likely that it was originally an open drain, formed from streams from three of the neighbouring hills, that were channelled through the main [[Roman Forum|Forum]] and then on to the Tiber.<ref name="iath.virginia.edu"/> This open drain would then have been gradually built over, as building space within the city became more valuable. It is possible that both theories are correct, and certainly some of the main lower parts of the system suggest that they would have been below ground level even at the time of the supposed construction.
The eleven [[Roman aqueduct|aqueducts]] which supplied water to Rome by the 1st century AD were finally channelled into the sewers after having supplied the many public baths such as the [[Baths of Diocletian]] and the [[Baths of Trajan]], the public fountains, imperial palaces and private houses.<ref>Woods, Michael (2000). ''Ancient medicine: from sorcery to surgery''. Twenty-First Century Books. {{ISBN|978-0-8225-2992-7}}, p.81.</ref><ref>[[Bertrand Lançon|Lançon, Bertrand]] (2000). ''Rome in late antiquity: everyday life and urban change, AD 312-609''. Routledge. {{ISBN|978-0-415-92975-2}}, p.13.</ref> The continuous supply of running water helped to remove wastes and keep the sewers clear of obstructions. The best waters were reserved for potable drinking supplies, and the second quality waters would be used by the baths, the outfalls of which connected to the sewer network under the streets of the city. The aqueduct system was investigated by the general [[Frontinus]] at the end of the 1st century AD, who published his report on its state directly to the emperor [[Nerva]].
==Distribution system== {{quote box |title = |quote = The extraordinary greatness of the Roman Empire manifests itself above all in three things: the aqueducts, the paved roads, and the construction of the drains. |source = [[Dionysius of Halicarnassus]], ''Ant. Rom. 3.67.5''<ref>Quilici, Lorenzo (2008): "Land Transport, Part 1: Roads and Bridges", in: [[John Peter Oleson|Oleson, John Peter]] (ed.): ''The Oxford Handbook of Engineering and Technology in the Classical World'', Oxford University Press, New York, {{ISBN|978-0-19-518731-1}}, pp. 551–579 (552)</ref>|align = right |width = 30em }}
There were many branches off the main sewer, but all seemed to be 'official' drains that would have served public toilets, bath-houses and other public buildings. Private residences in Rome, even of the rich, would have relied on some sort of [[cess-pit]] arrangement for sewage.
The Cloaca Maxima was well maintained throughout the life of the [[Roman Empire]] and even today drains rainwater and debris from the center of town, below the ancient Forum, Velabro and Foro Boario. In 33 BC it is known to have received an inspection and overhaul from [[Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa|Agrippa]], and [[archaeology]] reveals several building styles and material from various ages, suggesting that the systems received regular attention. In more recent times, the remaining passages have been connected to the modern-day sewage system, mainly to cope with problems of [[backwashing (water treatment)|backwash]] from the river.
[[File:040227 tevere16CloacaMaxima.jpg|thumb|Outfall of Cloaca Maxima as it appeared in 2005]]
The Cloaca Maxima was thought to be presided over by the goddess [[Cloacina]].
The Romans are recorded – the veracity of the accounts depending on the case – to have dragged the bodies of a number of people to the sewers rather than give them proper burial, among them the emperor [[Elagabalus]]<ref>[[Herodian]], ''Roman History'', 5.8.9</ref><ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/0/20627618</ref> and [[Saint Sebastian]]: the latter scene is the subject of a well-known artwork by [[Lodovico Carracci]].
The outfall of the Cloaca Maxima into the River Tiber is still visible today near the bridge [[Ponte Rotto]], and near Ponte Palatino. There is a stairway going down to it visible next to the [[Basilica Julia]] at the Forum. Some of it is also visible from the surface opposite the church of [[San Giorgio al Velabro]].
==The Empire== [[File:View of the Cloaca Maxima Rome 1814.jpg|thumb|View of the Cloaca Maxima as it appeared in 1814. Oil on canvas by [[Christoffer Wilhelm Eckersberg]]]] The system of [[Sanitation in ancient Rome|Roman sewers]] was much imitated throughout the Roman Empire, especially when combined with copious supplies of water from [[Roman aqueducts]]. The sewer system in [[Eboracum]]—the modern-day English city of [[York]]—was especially impressive and part of it still survives.<ref>Darvill, Timothy, Stamper, Paul and Timby, Jane (2002). ''England: an Oxford archaeological guide to sites from earliest times to AD 1600''. Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-19-284101-8}}, pp. 162-163.</ref>
==See also== *[[Aqueduct (Roman)]] *[[Barrel vault]] *[[List of Roman aqueducts by date]] *[[Sanitation in Ancient Rome]] {{-}}

Rinne] *[http://www3.iath.virginia.edu/waters/Journal4Hopkins.pdf ''The Waters of Rome'': "The Cloaca Maxima and the Monumental Manipulation of Water in Archaic Rome" by John N. N. Hopkins] *[http://www.livius.org/ro-rz/rome/rome_cloaca.html Rome: Cloaca Maxima]
